summary: the viral enzyme complex contains an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) as its core catalytic subunit for the production of negative strand RNA (–RNA), new genome molecules and in many virus groups also subgenomic (sg) messenger RNAs (mRNAs) (1,3) the group is also known for its exceptionally large polycistronic genome of 30 kb. the arterivirus and CoV sg RNAs derive from a discontinuous step during minus-strand RNA synthesis that is guided by specific RNA signals. this mechanism produces a set of subgenome-length negative-strand templates from which the sg mRNAs are produced. the unusual genome size of CoVs and the complexity of their RNA synthesis hint at an RdRp that may have special properties. the 932-amino-acid subunit, now known as nsp12, was confidently aligned with the conserved motifs of well-known viral RdRps (22,23). biochemical information on the CoV RdRp has, however, remained scarce thus far, particularly since full-length nsp12 was refractory to expression in bacterial systems. ubiquitin generates a recombinant nsp12 protein containing its natural N-terminus. full-length nsp12 can readily synthesize RNA in a primer-dependent fashion on homo- and
